head.title: Before the Next Flood or Heat Wave Hits

hedline.hl1: Before the Next Flood or Heat Wave Hits

block.p: The connection between our extreme weather events -- heat in the East, flooding in the Middle West -- and findings that climate stability can change more rapidly than previously appreciated must do more than raise eyebrows.

The connection between our extreme weather events -- heat in the East, flooding in the Middle West -- and findings that climate stability can change more rapidly than previously appreciated must do more than raise eyebrows.
Global weather patterns are influenced by the Pacific Ocean warming center, El Nino; when seas grow warm, evaporation increases, yielding abundant precipitation in some areas, a dearth in others.

This year's El Nino was unexpected, its persistence into summer unprecedented, and the endurance of negative sea surface pressures (a "depression") in the South Pacific that drive El Nino has, according to the National Meteorological Center, "no analogue in the historical record." The sea around us, Rachel Carson explained, is a global thermostat, and a warmed atmosphere transfers heat to the oceans for worldwide distribution. This global "conveyor belt" of ocean currents like the Gulf Stream may have flipped directions to initiate rapid climate changes in the past.

Felling forests and burning fossil fuels, remnants of buried life forms, drive climate change. But we do not have to wait for proof of global warming to infer that environmental and ecological changes threaten our health, homes and habitat.

A basic climate change policy has six elements: (1) energy efficiency; (2) renewable resources and co-generation; (3) rationalized transportation; (4) recycling; (5) tree planting, and (6) standards. Cities and towns can lead the way by putting these principles into practice; a national policy is due. PAUL R. EPSTEIN Cambridge, Mass., July 16, 1993
